link_counts.title: GitHub - Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve: AdvantageKitSwerve in off season
What are some ideas software-wise for this off-season?

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: I think the entire zoning approach is superfluous. Each reef face has an April tag, which can be converted to a Pose2d object. Using the robot pose, you can do robotPose.nearest(<list of reef poses from April tags>) and it will give you the closest one.
Thank you very much for your suggestion. I didn’t know that; however, I can update the project during my free time.

posts.name: Oliver

posts.cooked: Unfortunately, we were only able to incorporate coral into the L1 section since we've introduced an Everybot this year. Due to the absence of an elevator system available for real-life testing, I had to adapt the solution based on the L1 part.

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: We performed similar actions at runtime, starting from the closest tag to the pose2D of the target location for automatic alignment. The image illustrates the various regions involved in this process. By adding an offset for LEFT, RIGHT, or MIDDLE, we can adjust the alignment to match our desired side of the reef.

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: It’s still helpful to place the coral under the branch so that you can fit 2 side by side.
Yes, I had never thought of this code since we couldn't test it outside the simulation. Thanks again for your help.
Is there any way to see these fields on advantagescope? Was your team able to achieve this?

posts.name: Val DiBona
posts.cooked: I don’t think so. I’ll admit I was using Desmos for the graph. Another team coded something called 'region2d' and possibly made it loggable.

The cleaned-up text is:

"I came across this in the golden horn team’s behind-to-bumper video. It appears in the video starting at 4:37 minutes. I would be very happy if we can help each other on this subject."

This version removes unnecessary words, refines phrasing for clarity, and ensures proper punctuation while maintaining the original intent.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
This is an implementation of a PolygonRegion class that defines a region of the field using vertices. The code includes a GitHub blob for documentation, containing the complete class definition along with helper methods and comments. An example demonstrates how to create a region shaped as a rectangle centered around the field's center. Logs are utilized to record the region's points in a format compatible with AdvantageScope.

The implementation uses a GitHub blob to store documentation, containing the full class source and comments explaining its structure and usage. An example shows creating a rectangular region centered on the field with specific dimensions relative to the field's edges. Logs are used to track the region's geometry in real-time, aiding in debugging and analysis.

An additional example illustrates how to define a complex polygon with five vertices, approximating a specific area near the right and left sides of the field. The code snippet demonstrates defining a polygonal region with precise coordinates relative to the field, facilitating accurate field mapping and navigation.

The implementation leverages the OpenCV Geometry module to handle geometric transformations and calculations. A helper method initializes the region with translated points based on given parameters, allowing flexible configuration for different regions of interest.

The GitHub repository hosts the complete source files, enabling easy access and modification for users. This approach provides a robust foundation for implementing field-based strategies, leveraging Python's capabilities for precise control over robot movements and interactions with the environment.

Thank you for being one of the inspirations for me in this project. I’ve reviewed your code, but I’m still unclear about how you redirect these fields to advantagescope. Please don’t hesitate to reach out if you need further assistance.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
We utilize a **StructArrayPublisher** from the AdvantageScope documentation page. For example, you can find a similar implementation using poses on the [Odometry](https://docs.advantagescope.org/tab-reference/odometry) page.

Our implementation is straightforward. We define the region using an array of `Translation2d` objects within the `PolygonRegion` constructor. Refer to the [GitHub repository](https://github.com/FRC-Team-4143/mainbot-2025/blob/af933ead440049fdd6b675a961c8f6d460a8c862/src/main/java/frc/mw_lib/geometry/PolygonRegion.java) for details, particularly lines 30–33, where we set up a struct array publisher akin to the AdvantageScope example but using `Translation2d` instead of `Pose2d`.

Finally, we call the `logPoints` method, which sends the `Translation2d` array defined in the class constructor to a custom publisher. Unfortunately, one of the links appears inconsistent with the rest of the content and has been removed for clarity.

posts.name: Cole Hunt
posts.cooked:
It appears your implementation differs from ours. You currently utilize a single class that examines a fixed set of predefined points. In contrast, our solution is designed to handle polygons of any size or shape universally. To implement this effectively, consider creating multiple PolygonRegion objects to delineate various field zones.

To proceed with your current strategy, ensure each point in your zone polygon is associated with either a Pose2d or Translation2d array. For instance:

```java
Translation2d[] yellowRegion = new Translation2d[]{new Translation2d(4.501, 6.176), new Translation2d(8.768, 8.000)};
```

When published to NT using a StructArrayPublisher, such a configuration may appear as a line in AdvantageScope. Below is an example of a Translation2d array tailored for our loading station zone, shaped like a triangle in the field's corner:

```java
new Translation2d[]{new Translation2d(0, 0), new Translation2d(0, 4), new Translation2d(4.5, 0), new Translation2d(0, 0)}
```

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
You can! The `Field2D` object supports arbitrary objects via `field.getObject("name")`. Our testing involved simulating the chassis, grabbing the nearest tag and setting its pose on the field, generating appropriate transformations and adding them to the field, and repeating this process for other items of interest.

If you want to create lines, you can use the `.setPoses(...)` method and adjust the display style on the dashboard. On Glass, there are several display options for useful visualizations, though specifics for AdvantageScope aren’t clear. Additionally, you can set poses using field trajectories and perform other tasks like assigning images to specific object names.

Thank you very much for your help. I finally managed to add these lines with the help of chatgpt and pushed the new code to the repo; you can check it if you want. However, the comment lines are currently written in Turkish for my team to understand temporarily. Once I'm done translating all these lines into English, I'd appreciate it if you could disregard this note.

user.name: Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)
